questions.text: A 31-year-old man has had a year's history of bilateral hip pain and back pain with early morning stiffness. There is no past medical history of trauma to the back. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs helped to relieve his symptoms. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sacroiliitis refers to inflammation of the sacroiliac joints, and is commonly seen in seronegative spondyloarthropathies such as:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Psoriatic arthritis
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Arthritis associated with IBD

Key features include:

  • Insidious onset of low back and buttock pain, often bilateral.
  • Prominent early morning stiffness, which improves with exercise.
  • A good response to NSAIDs is characteristic.
  • X-rays or MRI may reveal sacroiliac joint inflammation or erosions.

Explanation of other options:

Gluteus medius tendonitis (Option A): This causes lateral hip pain that worsens with movement or pressure over the outer hip. It does not involve back pain or morning stiffness, and is mechanical, not inflammatory.

Osteoarthritis (Option B): OA typically affects older adults and causes activity-related joint pain with minimal morning stiffness (<30 mins). It is uncommon in young adults and not associated with inflammatory features.

Hip fracture (Option C): Usually follows trauma and presents with acute, severe pain and difficulty bearing weight. It would not cause chronic back stiffness in a healthy 31-year-old with no injury history.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has a 3-month history of arthralgia, joint pain, and early morning stiffness. There is swelling of the distal interphalangeal joints of the ring fingers of the hand. The wrist on the right and the ankles are swollen as well. Onycholysis was noted on the nails. Her serum inflammatory markers are raised. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has inflammatory arthritis characterized by:

  • 3 months of arthralgia and early morning stiffness (inflammatory type)
  • Asymmetric involvement of the DIP joints, wrist, and ankles
  • Onycholysis (nail change) and raised inflammatory markers

Key Diagnostic Clues:

  • DIP joint involvement: Peripheral arthritis in psoriatic arthritis (PsA) commonly affects DIP joints of the hands, a feature that distinguishes it from RA, which typically spares DIPs.
  • Nail changes: Onycholysis, pitting, and ridging are highly characteristic of PsA and are part of the CASPAR diagnostic criteria.
  • Patterns of presentation: According to Wright and Moll, five classic patterns occur:
    • DIP-predominant arthritis
    • Asymmetric oligoarthritis
    • Symmetric polyarthritis (RA-like)
    • Axial involvement (spondylitis/sacroiliitis)
    • Arthritis mutilans
  • This patient fits the DIP + asymmetric oligoarthritis pattern.
  • About 70% of patients develop arthritis after skin psoriasis, but in up to 15% arthritis may precede visible skin lesions.
  • CASPAR criteria: Inflammatory articular disease + features like psoriasis, nail dystrophy, negative RF, dactylitis, or juxta-articular new bone formation.
  • Radiographic hallmark: pencil-in-cup deformity

Explanation of other options:

Polymyalgia rheumatica (Option A): Occurs in age >50 years with shoulder/hip pain, not small joint swelling or DIP involvement.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option B): Symmetrical polyarthritis sparing DIPs; no nail changes.

Gout (Option C): Typically acute monoarthritis of the first MTP; chronic tophi seen in long-standing disease, not DIP + nail involvement.

Key Takeaway:

DIP joint swelling combined with onycholysis and asymmetric oligoarthritis in a young adult is classic for psoriatic arthritis

choices.text: Psoriatic skin lesions are universally present in all patients with Psoriatic arthritis
The presence of axial spondylitis involving the Thoracolumbar spine favors the diagnosis of Psoriatic Arthritis
The presence of acute anterior uveitis favours the diagnosis of Psoriatic arthritis
The presence of nail changes favours the diagnosis of Psoriatic arthritis

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with symmetric polyarthritis involving the small joints of the hands, excluding the DIP, along with both wrist joints of 3 months duration. Which of the following statements favours the diagnosis of Psoriatic arthritis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 55-year-old man presents with symmetric small-joint arthritis sparing the DIP joints, which closely resembles RA.

In such cases, the distinguishing feature pointing to psoriatic arthritis (PsA) rather than RA is the presence of nail changes.

Key Points:

  1. Skin lesions are not universal:
    • 70% of PsA patients have skin psoriasis at presentation.
    • 15%: Skin and arthritis appear within a year of each other.
    • 15%: Arthritis may appear before skin lesions.
    • Therefore, the absence of psoriasis does not exclude PsA.
  2. Nail changes in PsA:
    • Seen in most PsA patients.
    • Typical changes:
      • Nail pitting
      • Onycholysis (nail separation)
      • Yellow-brown discoloration ("oil drop" sign)
      • Horizontal ridges and hyperkeratosis
  3. Axial involvement differences:
    • PsA: The cervical spine is more commonly affected.
    • Ankylosing spondylitis (AS): The thoracolumbar spine is predominantly affected.
  4. Uveitis differences:
    • AS: Acute anterior uveitis (sudden onset, unilateral).
    • PsA: Chronic, bilateral posterior uveitis (slower onset).

Explanation of other options:

Psoriatic skin lesions are universally present in all patients with Psoriatic arthritis (Option A): Incorrect: Only 70% have skin lesions at presentation.

Presence of axial spondylitis involving the thoracolumbar spine (Option B): More typical of AS, not PsA.

Presence of acute anterior uveitis (Option C): Acute anterior uveitis is typical of AS, not PsA.

questions.text: A 55 year old female, presents with joint pain and stiffness involving the MCP, PIP and DIP of the index finger of the left hand. The rest of the fingers are spared. What arthritis is it most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The pattern of involvement described is the "ray" pattern, where all the joints of a finger are involved, sparing other fingers. It is seen in PsA.

questions.text: The hand X-ray of a patient with chronic arthritis is given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The hand X-ray shows a classic "pencil-in-cup" deformity:

  • Appearance:
    • The end of a phalanx becomes tapered (pencil-like) and fits into the expanded, eroded surface of the adjacent bone (cup-like).
    • This occurs due to erosion and bone resorption (osteolysis) at the joint margins, combined with new bone formation.
  • Association:
    • This deformity is characteristic of psoriatic arthritis (PsA), particularly in long-standing, destructive disease.
    • It often occurs in the DIP joints and can lead to arthritis mutilans.

questions.text: A patient comes with features of Sacroiliitis. Which of the following features makes the diagnosis of PsA rather than AS?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sacroiliitis can occur in multiple spondyloarthritides (AS, PsA, reactive arthritis, IBD-related).

To differentiate psoriatic arthritis (PsA) from ankylosing spondylitis (AS), specific radiologic patterns are key:

Explanation of other options:

Symmetrical sacroiliitis (Option A): Symmetrical sacroiliitis is typical of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) rather than psoriatic arthritis. PsA more commonly shows asymmetric involvement of sacroiliac joints, so symmetrical disease points away from PsA.

Marginal syndesmophytes (Option C): Thin, vertical, marginal syndesmophytes are a classic radiological hallmark of AS. In contrast, PsA has non-marginal, bulky, comma-shaped syndesmophytes.

Squaring of vertebral body (Option D): Squaring of vertebral bodies and "bamboo spine" are features of AS, caused by inflammation at vertebral corners and subsequent repair. This is not a characteristic finding in psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following interleukins chiefly drives PsA?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The IL-23 / IL-17 axis is central to the pathogenesis of psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
  • IL-23 promotes differentiation and survival of Th17 cells, which in turn produce IL-17.
  • These cytokines drive:
    • Chronic synovial inflammation
    • Enthesitis and new bone formation
    • Keratinocyte proliferation in psoriasis
  • Therapies based on this pathway:
    • Anti-IL-17: Secukinumab, Ixekizumab
    • Anti-IL-23 / IL-12 (p40): Ustekinumab
    • Anti-IL-23 (p19): Guselkumab, Risankizumab, Tildrakizumab

These biologics have shown high efficacy in PsA and psoriasis.

Explanation of other options:

IL-6 (Option B): Important in RA and systemic inflammation; blockade used in RA (tocilizumab), not a key driver of PsA.

IL-1 (Option C): Implicated in autoinflammatory syndromes (e.g., Still's disease).

IL-13 (Option D): Associated with atopic dermatitis and asthma, not PsA.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with long-standing psoriasis presents with significant joint pain and stiffness. Which one of the following is most effective in her treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Methotrexate is a conventional Disease-Modifying Anti-Rheumatic Drug (DMARD) that is commonly used to treat psoriatic arthritis (PsA), especially in patients not requiring biologics.

  • It has moderate efficacy for both skin and joint symptoms.
  • Often used as first-line therapy in mild to moderate PsA.
  • Doses: 15-25 mg/week.

Other Effective Treatment Options for Psoriatic Arthritis:

Biologic Agents (For Moderate to Severe PsA):

1. Anti-TNF agents:

  • Etanercept, Infliximab, Adalimumab, Golimumab, Certolizumab
  • Dramatic improvement in both skin and joints
  • May paradoxically trigger new/worsening psoriasis in some

2. IL-17/IL-23 Pathway Inhibitors:

  • IL-17A: Secukinumab, Ixekizumab
  • IL-12/23 (p40): Ustekinumab
  • IL-23 (p19): Guselkumab, Risankizumab, Tildrakizumab
  • Often superior to anti-TNF in controlling psoriasis

Targeted Synthetic DMARDs:

3. Tofacitinib (JAK inhibitor):

  • Oral agent approved for PsA
  • Comparable to Adalimumab in trials

4. Apremilast (PDE-4 inhibitor):

  • Oral medication
  • Modest efficacy but favorable safety profile
  • Not used in cases with radiographic joint damage or axial involvement

Other Conventional DMARDs:

5. Leflunomide:

  • Pyrimidine synthesis inhibitor
  • Modest joint and skin benefits

6. Cyclosporine, Retinoids, PUVA (Psoralen + UVA light):

  • Primarily useful for skin symptoms, limited joint benefit

Explanation of other options:

Codeine phosphate (Option A): An opioid analgesic. Provides only symptomatic pain relief, with no impact on disease progression. Not a disease-modifying agent; not used in PsA treatment.

Beta interferon (Option C): Used primarily in multiple sclerosis. Has no role in PsA treatment and may worsen psoriasis, especially the palmoplantar pustular variant.

Capecitabine (Option D): A chemotherapy drug (prodrug of 5-fluorouracil) used in breast and colorectal cancer. Not used for autoimmune or inflammatory joint conditions. It may even cause cutaneous adverse effects.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with longstanding psoriasis has a six-week history of persistently swollen, painful, and tender right knee. The early morning stiffness lasts for over an hour, and he has partial relief from the use of NSAIDs. He is negative for rheumatoid factors. A knee x-ray is normal. What is the next step in his long-term management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient with longstanding psoriasis now has:

  • Persistent inflammatory monoarthritis (knee) for 6 weeks
  • Morning stiffness > 1 hour, partial relief with NSAIDs
  • RF negative, normal X-ray

These features indicate peripheral psoriatic arthritis (PsA) that is not adequately controlled with NSAIDs.

Treatment for PsA :

  1. Biologics (anti-TNF, IL-17/23 inhibitors, JAK inhibitors):
    • Highly effective, especially in long-standing, resistant, or extensive disease and in axial PsA.
    • Anti-TNF agents can dramatically control both skin and joint disease, but are not first-line for uncomplicated peripheral arthritis.
  2. Apremilast (PDE-4 inhibitor):
    • Oral option, safer but less effective.
    • Not indicated if there is radiographic damage or axial disease.
  3. JAK inhibitors (e.g., tofacitinib):
    • Newer oral option; efficacy comparable to anti-TNF in trials.
  4. Conventional DMARDs:
    • Methotrexate (15-25 mg/week):
      • Moderate efficacy in psoriasis and PsA.
      • Favored in PsA not requiring biologics (i.e., without severe/axial disease).
    • Leflunomide: modest benefit for both joints and skin.
    • Cyclosporine, retinoids, PUVA: primarily for skin.

Next step for this patient:

  • Since NSAIDs alone are insufficient, the next step is to initiate a conventional DMARD (e.g., methotrexate).
  • Biologics (anti-TNF or IL-17/23 inhibitors) are reserved for:
    • Axial PsA
    • Radiographic damage
    • Severe disease not responding to DMARDs

Explanation for other options:

Alternative NSAID (Option A): NSAIDs relieve pain but do not prevent progression.

Anti-TNF agents (Option B): Very effective but reserved for axial or refractory PsA.

Intra-articular corticosteroids (Option D): Provide short-term relief but do not modify long-term disease course. Systemic corticosteroids are avoided in psoriasis because of the risk of pustular psoriasis.

choices.text: Arthroscopy and washout of the joint
If the symptoms become chronic, sulphasalazine may be useful

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents with a painful, swollen knee. He feels generally unwell and has a fever. He has recently had a flu-like illness, an erythematous rash on the trunk, followed by a self-limiting episode of diarrhoea. How should the patient be managed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has reactive arthritis, which typically occurs 1-4 weeks after an infection (commonly gastrointestinal or genitourinary).

  • Initial management includes NSAIDs for symptom relief.
  • Joint aspiration may help exclude septic arthritis, but invasive procedures like arthroscopy are usually not needed unless the diagnosis is uncertain.
  • If arthritis becomes chronic or persistent, DMARDs like sulfasalazine or methotrexate are indicated.
  • Sulfasalazine is particularly useful in chronic reactive arthritis.

Explanation of other options:

High-dose steroids (Option A): Systemic steroids are not first-line for acute reactive arthritis. Reserved for severe or refractory cases, and even then, used cautiously. Initial treatment should focus on NSAIDs and supportive care.

Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics (Option B): There is no active infection-the triggering infection (likely enteric) has resolved. Antibiotics are not useful once reactive arthritis is established. They may only be indicated during the initial infection, not after joint symptoms develop.

Arthroscopy and washout of the joint (Option C): Indicated for septic arthritis, not reactive arthritis. This patient lacks features suggestive of purulent joint infection (e.g., grossly purulent aspirate, positive cultures). Aspiration may be done to rule out infection, but arthroscopy is not necessary here.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of low back pain. The pain radiates to his buttocks. There is associated stiffness, which is worse in the morning and after periods of inactivity. Which of the following signs is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 28-year-old man has chronic low back pain (6 months) with these classical features of inflammatory back pain:

  1. Age at onset < 40 years
  2. Gradual onset, not sudden
  3. Pain and stiffness worse in the morning and after rest
  4. Improves with exercise
  5. Pain radiates to the buttocks and may be alternating

These features are hallmarks of axial spondyloarthritis (SpA), particularly ankylosing spondylitis

Key Examination Finding:

  • Tenderness of the sacroiliac joints is the earliest and most consistent sign.
  • Additional tests: FABER (Patrick) test, Gaenslen's test, and direct SI joint palpation.
  • Schober's test and decreased lumbar flexion appear later.

Explanation of other options:

Foot drop (Option A): Suggests nerve root compression (disc prolapse, mechanical pathology). Not typical of inflammatory back pain.

Positive femoral stretch test (Option B): Indicates upper lumbar nerve root irritation (L2-L4). Seen in disc herniation or spinal stenosis, not spondyloarthritis.

Positive Trendelenburg test (Option C): Suggests hip abductor weakness or hip joint pathology, not SI inflammation.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man has difficulty bending to touch his toes when bending over. He has lower back pain, stiffness in the thoracic region, and reduced chest expansion. His lower spine X-ray is shown above.

He has negative rheumatoid factor and a HLA-B27 genotype. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 46-year-old man presents with:

  • Chronic inflammatory low back pain
    • Pain worse in the morning and after rest
    • Improves with activity
  • Stiffness in the thoracic spine
  • Reduced chest expansion
  • HLA-B27 positive and negative rheumatoid factor

X-ray findings (lateral lumbar spine):

  • Shows thin vertical bony ridges bridging adjacent vertebral bodies (marginal syndesmophytes).

This clinical + radiological pattern is characteristic of Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS).

Clinical Features of Ankylosing Spondylitis:

  1. Inflammatory low back pain:
    • Pain in the lumbar or gluteal region
    • Morning stiffness > 30 min, improves with activity, recurs after rest
    • Pain becomes persistent and bilateral as the disease progresses
    • Night pain that improves upon waking
  2. Reduced spinal mobility:
    • Difficulty bending (e.g., touching toes)
    • Limitations of spinal movements
    • Decreased chest expansion due to costovertebral and costosternal involvement
  3. Enthesitis:
    • Pain at the tendon and ligament insertion sites:
      • Costochondral junctions
      • Iliac crest
      • Greater trochanter, etc.
  4. Hip and shoulder joint arthritis:
    • Considered part of axial arthritis rather than peripheral arthritis.

Genetics:

  • HLA-B27 positivity:
    • Present in 85-90% of AS patients
    • AS is found in 1-6% of adults with HLA-B27
    • More than 115 other genetic alleles also play a role

Radiological Features of AS:

  1. Sacroiliitis (earliest sign):
    • Blurring of cortical margins → erosions and sclerosis
    • Pseudowidening of the joint space
    • Ankylosis and bony obliteration in advanced disease
    • MRI STIR sequences can show early sacroiliitis before plain X-ray changes
  2. Spine:
    • Romanus lesions: erosions at the anterior vertebral corners
    • Marginal syndesmophytes: vertical bony ridges bridging vertebrae
    • Fusion of vertebral bodies → "Bamboo spine"

Explanation of other options:

Paget's disease (Option A): Shows coarse trabeculae, cortical thickening, and bone expansion (not thin vertical syndesmophytes).

Osteoarthritis (Option B): Shows horizontal, bulky osteophytes and facet joint changes, not thin vertical syndesmophytes. Sacroiliac joints typically remain normal.

Marfan's syndrome (Option C): Characterized by tall stature, long limbs, lens subluxation, and aortic root disease. No inflammatory back pain or syndesmophytes.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man complaining of low back pain and stiffness, gradually increasing in severity for six months, presents to the outpatient department. He has no past medical history, and the only medications he takes are anti-inflammatories that ease the pain. On examination, his back movements are stiff with decreased range of movement due to pain. A diagnosis of AS was made. He does not improve with NSAIDs. What is the next line of treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Stepwise treatment of Axial Spondyloarthritis (Ax-SpA/AS):

  1. Non-pharmacologic:
    • Exercise and posture training are essential to maintain spinal flexibility.
  2. First-line drug therapy:
    • NSAIDs (e.g., indomethacin, naproxen) are the first-line agents.
    • They improve pain, stiffness, and mobility. Continuous high-dose NSAIDs may slow radiographic progression.
  3. If symptoms persist despite NSAIDs:
    • Biologic therapy is indicated.
    • Anti-TNF agents (infliximab, etanercept, adalimumab, golimumab, certolizumab pegol) are the mainstay for persistent active axial disease.
      • These drugs improve pain, stiffness, ESR/CRP, MRI inflammation, and function.
      • They may slow the formation of syndesmophytes if started early.
    • IL-17 inhibitors (secukinumab, ixekizumab) are alternatives, especially for patients who fail or cannot tolerate TNF inhibitors.
  4. Other drugs:
    • JAK inhibitors (tofacitinib, upadacitinib, filgotinib): Effective in trials but not first-line.
    • Sulfasalazine: Only for peripheral joint involvement.
    • Methotrexate and systemic glucocorticoids: Not effective for axial disease.
    • IL-23 inhibitors: Not effective in AS.

Explanation of other options:

Methotrexate (Option B): No benefit in axial disease; only for peripheral arthritis.

Cyclosporine (Option C): Not effective in AS.

Cyclophosphamide (Option D): Used for systemic vasculitis/malignancy; not indicated in AS.

choices.text: Inflammatory arthritis associated with inflammatory bowel disease

questions.text: A 37-year-old publican with a two-month history of bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and weight loss presents with a three-week history of painful and swollen left knee. There is no other significant past or family history. Stool cultures done by her GP have been negative for C. difficile toxin and have not grown any pathogenic organisms. On examination, the left knee is warm, tender, and there is a large effusion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This 37-year-old patient has:

  • Two months of bloody diarrhoea with negative stool cultures, suggesting IBD (ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease) rather than an acute infection.
  • Painful, swollen knee appearing while the bowel symptoms are active.

IBD-Associated Arthritis:

Epidemiology:

  • Peripheral arthritis occurs in 10-50% of IBD patients, and inflammatory back pain (IBP), enthesitis, and sacroiliitis are also common.

Clinical Features:

  • Peripheral arthritis often presents as acute, self-limited oligoarthritis coinciding with relapses of IBD.
  • The large joints of the lower extremities (knees, ankles) are typically involved.
  • A chronic symmetric polyarthritis can also occur and may run an independent course from bowel disease.
  • Erosions and deformities are uncommon; dactylitis and enthesopathy may occur.

Diagnosis:

  • When diarrhoea and arthritis occur together, the most common related causes are reactive arthritis and IBD-associated arthritis.
  • In this patient, ongoing diarrhoea with negative stool cultures and concurrent joint involvement points toward IBD-associated arthritis rather than reactive arthritis, which usually appears after an infection has resolved.

Explanation of other options:

Carcinomatous arthropathy (Option A): Paraneoplastic arthritis is usually seen in patients with known or occult malignancy and typically presents as a migratory polyarthritis. It is not associated with chronic diarrhoea, and there are no features of cancer in this patient.

Gout (Option B): Gout classically presents as an acute monoarthritis, most often in the first MTP joint (podagra). It is linked to hyperuricemia and risk factors like alcohol or diuretics, none of which are present here, and it is not associated with chronic bowel symptoms.

Reactive arthritis (Option D): Reactive arthritis occurs 1-4 weeks after a diarrhoeal or urogenital infection has resolved. In this case, the arthritis developed while diarrhoea was ongoing for two months, making IBD-related arthritis more likely.
